SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. He has been experiencing these symptoms for about five weeks. He has been involved in home renovation projects and has had difficulty maintaining a healthy diet due to the construction in his kitchen. He denies fever, chills, and abdominal pain but endorses shortness of breath during exertion and occasional chest cramps. He also reports a slight cough.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Fatigue, lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Shortness of breath during exertion, occasional chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Bloating.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Lungs: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in the lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest x-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Patient to weigh themselves daily and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Patient to continue recording blood pressures at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder and stumbled, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help. She denies any other injuries. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a nose job. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stress. Normal sensation in the lower extremity. No calf pain.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus strain.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for re-evaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He reports taking Tylenol, ibuprofen, and using icy heat, which did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right foot toes until Sunday afternoon, which then resolved.

Regarding his diabetes, the patient admits to having a sweet tooth and not maintaining a stellar diet recently. He is taking his medication as prescribed.

Regarding his hypertension, the patient monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication as prescribed.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, the patient reports occasional aggravation but overall manageable pain.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Endorses weight gain.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Endorses tingling in right foot toes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment and no fracture present.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue to ice the area and avoid strenuous activity. Refer to physical therapy for further management.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been compliant with medication, but his recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing a good job monitoring his knee and managing pain.
• Medical Treatment: No further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam. Ralph reports that he has been managing his depression well with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He has been struggling more with his hypertension, admitting to occasionally forgetting to take his Norvasc medication on weekends. Ralph had a lobectomy a couple of years ago and has experienced some shortness of breath during the heat and pollen season. He also experiences shortness of breath with exertion while running 4-5 miles daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Nasal congestion from pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Chest pounding during exertion.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Depression managed with Prozac.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Well-managed with Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill ordered.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to continue current management strategies.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Controlled, but patient admits to occasional non-compliance on weekends.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to maintain medication compliance.

3. Status post lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: No current issues, shortness of breath during heat and pollen season.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

4. Shortness of breath with exertion.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Will follow up with results and discuss any necessary changes in management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident. She reports that her finger was bent backwards while skiing over moguls four days ago. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain management but reports continued pain.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger, obtained on today's visit, show no fractures and normal alignment.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. The patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up if the pain does not improve within a week. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia and related symptoms.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and increased sensitivity to cold. She also mentions worsening anxiety and depression. The patient has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.
Anxiety.
Depression.

Gynecologic History
Hysterectomy in 1996.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: Occasional, once or twice a year.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not mentioned.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
Over-the-counter Vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
Respiratory: Normal lung sounds.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no masses or organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia with related symptoms.

PLAN

1. Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed.
2. Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for the next 12 weeks.
3. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate after 12 weeks.
4. Referral to hematologist for further evaluation and management.
5. Consider capsule endoscopy if upper endoscopy and colonoscopy are inconclusive.

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy.
2. Schedule an appointment with a hematologist.
3. Follow bowel prep instructions for colonoscopy.
4. Call the clinic with any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient initially presented to his primary care provider, Dr. Henry Howard, on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches in the past. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size, and no other abnormalities are noted.

The patient describes the headaches as a dull, nagging ache located behind his eyes, with a severity of 6 out of 10. The headaches have been gradually worsening over the past three months and tend to be worse in the morning. They last for a few hours at a time, and nothing seems to make them better or worse. The patient denies any other symptoms such as fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has noticed recently that he seems to be bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
None.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer.
Marital status: Married for 25 years.
Recently bought a small house.
No history of alcohol, smoking, or recreational drug use.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Tylenol (tried for headaches, but discontinued due to lack of efficacy).

RESULTS

MRI brain with contrast (3/4/21): Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa due to symptomatic clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression.
2. Refer the patient to the eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map out peripheral vision prior to surgery.
3. Schedule surgery with the transsphenoidal approach for minimally invasive removal of the pituitary adenoma.
4. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.
5. Follow up with the patient post-surgery to monitor vision improvement and address any complications.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred in October 2020. The patient reports that the chest pain lasted for four days and was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone. The pain was sharp and felt worse with eating. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient visited the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, which were normal. The ER suspected a GI issue and referred her to our clinic. The patient's symptoms resolved approximately three days after her ER visit and have not recurred since.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Gallbladder removal (several years ago).

SOCIAL HISTORY

No significant social history reported.

FAMILY HISTORY

No significant family history of GI problems.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for abdominal pain and bowel movement issues.
Positive for chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, which have since resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other significant findings.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, with possible etiologies including GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal causes, and anxiety. The patient reported a stressful job transition around the time of the symptoms, suggesting a possible anxiety attack contributing to her condition.

PLAN

1. The patient will self-monitor her symptoms and call the office if any additional episodes of pain or other concerning symptoms occur.
2. If symptoms recur, the patient will be scheduled for an EGD to further evaluate her esophagus and stomach.
3. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up for Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, including stopping breathing while eating, and severe reflux. She has seen multiple specialists, including a GI doctor, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic doctor, and ophthalmologist. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will start speech therapy soon. Katherine has a 9-year-old brother with autism.

The patient's geneticist mentioned that individuals with Smith-Magenis Syndrome may have kidney anomalies and issues with their legs. The patient is currently drinking Ripple Pea Protein milk, water, and occasionally water with a small amount of juice. She has approximately 8-10 wet diapers in a 24-hour period.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Prematurity.
Feeding difficulties.
Severe reflux.

FAMILY HISTORY

9-year-old brother with autism.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None mentioned.

EXAMINATION

Physical exam shows a well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. She has mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with possible congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.
2. If abnormalities are found on the kidney ultrasound, determine next steps and future follow-up.
3. Follow-up should be at the Town Center location, as the family lives in Dallas, Georgia.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a 42-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her arms outstretched. She reports that her right wrist started to hurt severely and became swollen. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The injury occurred yesterday morning. She denies any previous injuries to this arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20 bpm
Temp: 97.2°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower edema, palpable pulses.
Right wrist: Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Limited range of motion. Swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively at first, with a brace for her right wrist. We will also schedule surgery for the patient as soon as possible. In the meantime, I will prescribe 50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours for pain management. After surgery, the patient will be referred to physical therapy for rehabilitation. The patient will follow up in a month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to follow the prescribed pain management regimen and to attend physical therapy sessions as recommended. She should contact the office if her pain worsens or if she experiences any complications.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago. He felt a pop in his knee and has been experiencing pain and swelling since the incident.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, currently on 20 mg Lisinopril.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect. Pain with flexion and extension. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were identified.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with a medial collateral ligament strain.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support. Recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily to reduce swelling. Advise the patient to elevate and rest the leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg Lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg. Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary counseling to help manage hypertension and potentially reduce the need for medication.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects that the pain might be related to that activity. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain. The pain occurs occasionally, less than once a day, and is described as a sudden giving out sensation while walking. The pain is located internally in the knee and resolves quickly. The patient denies any history of injury to the knee and has not taken any medications for pain. The knee pain has not significantly interfered with her daily activities, but she is concerned about an upcoming trip that will involve walking and line dancing.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, diabetes mellitus.

MEDICATIONS

Farxiga, amlodipine, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2, pulse 72, respirations 16, blood pressure 122/70.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, or effusion; no pain to palpation; full range of motion; negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For left knee pain, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sore throat and cough.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three nonsmall cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She reports a persistent sore throat and a dry cough for the past few days.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient has a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, biopsy positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family members and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and sore throat.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest.
Lower extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has stage three nonsmall cell lung cancer and is currently undergoing chemotherapy and radiation.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with the current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation dose (45 Gy). Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to assess tumor response and potential for surgical intervention.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles on lung exam suggest radiation-induced inflammation.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat may be related to inflammation in the esophagus.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports frequent colds during wintertime. Patient's family owns a donut shop. No known family history of immune deficiencies. Recently diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes and started on Metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal infections or diarrhea.

VITALS

No fever or concerning vitals.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Neck
- Examination: No lymphadenopathy.

Abdominal
- Examination: Soft, non-tender.

RESULTS

Lab work consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work shows a low IgA level, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives without complications. Some may experience frequent respiratory, sinus, or abdominal infections, but this does not seem to be the case for the patient.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The nature of the diagnosis was discussed with the patient. We discussed the possibility of other immunodeficiencies and will order additional blood work to check other antibodies. The patient was advised to watch for infections that do not resolve or worsen and to inform any healthcare provider of their IgA deficiency if they require blood products.
- Medical Treatment: No specific treatment at this time. Will monitor the patient and follow up with additional blood work.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. The pain is localized to the medial aspect of his elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain is rated as 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK:
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Positive for pain with pronation of the forearm. Positive for pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is also instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is advised to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to evaluate the patient's progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent hospitalization for congestive heart failure.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during physical activity.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: Not reported
Heart Rate: Not reported
Oxygen Saturation: Not reported

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: Likely caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to continue taking medications consistently, monitor diet, and limit sodium intake.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of taking medications consistently and monitoring diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney stones.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of kidney stones. The patient was referred from his primary care physician. He has been experiencing sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. He reports some burning sensation during urination and darker urine at times. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief, but it has not been effective. The patient has a history of kidney stones and has been able to pass them in the past. His father also had kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Genitourinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and darker urine at times.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone.

PLAN

We reviewed the patient's CT results in detail today. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. I have prescribed the patient oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain. He may continue to take Tylenol between the oxycodone doses for any breakthrough pain. The patient will be provided with a strainer to use when urinating to catch the stone for further testing. I have also recommended that we obtain a BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1 to 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his symptoms have not improved, we will discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy. The patient is advised to contact me if he experiences worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 79-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for about six weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The blister has since unroofed, revealing thick, soft, mushy skin with a foul smell and yellow drainage. He has been on antibiotics for six days, and initially experienced some improvement, but now reports blackening of the wound edges and cramping in his calf muscle. He also mentions a red streak extending up his calf and increased warmth in the area. He has a history of well-controlled diabetes with a recent A1c of 6.7, but has noticed blood sugars trending higher in the past few weeks.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently tried a new pair of diabetic shoes.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports coughing and difficulty catching breath.
Skin: Reports non-healing right foot ulcer.
Neurological: No numbness or tingling.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure and heart rate within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
RESPIRATORY: No abnormalities noted.
SKIN: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythema, and foul odor. No bony exposure.
NECK: No abnormalities noted.
MSK: Pain and swelling in right calf.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed the following steps:

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement of the wound in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture of the wound and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on results.
4. Monitor the redness and swelling in the calf closely and schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
5. Encourage the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist to maintain good blood sugar control.

The patient understands the plan and has no further questions or concerns at this time.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and working in the yard. Patient noticed a tick bite on the right knee over a week ago, which has been causing burning and discomfort. Patient denies fever or chills but reports feeling generally unwell and experiencing headaches since the tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril.
Diabetes: Controlled with metformin.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Right knee: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over right patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite with concern for Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Presence of bull's-eye rash and patient's history of outdoor activities.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 3 weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day. Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
